explanation.rules:
Syllable Definitions 
There are two types of syllables: light and heavy.
Light Syllable : A light syllable consists of an optional consonant followed by a short vowel.
Formula: (C)V
Heavy Syllable : A heavy syllable has one of the following three structures:
An optional consonant followed by a long vowel. Formula: (C)V:
An optional consonant and a short vowel followed by another consonant (a closed syllable). Formula: (C)VC'
An optional consonant and a long vowel followed by another consonant. Formula: (C)V:C'
In these formulas, C and C' represent consonants, and V represents a vowel.

Word Structure and Stress Placement Rule
The structure of a word is composed of three parts, read from left to right: an initial section, a stressed section, and an optional final syllable.
Word = (Initial Section) (Stressed Section) [Optional Final Syllable]

Initial Section:
This section can be repeated zero or more times at the beginning of a word.
It consists of pairs of syllables in one of the following combinations:
Two light syllables 
A light syllable followed by a heavy syllable 
Two heavy syllables 

Stressed Section:
This section carries the primary stress of the word (indicated by the ‘).
It must match one of these four patterns:
A single stressed light syllable
A pair of light syllables with stress on the second syllable
A light syllable followed by a stressed heavy syllable
A single stressed heavy syllable

Optional Final Syllable:
A word may end with one optional, unstressed light syllable.
